website_summaries.verdict: A good sized field guide for both beginners and advanced birders, this guide features more than 1,000 species of birds.
pros: Beautifully illustrated, with more than 1,000 species of birds
Easy to use, and a good size for the field
Matches the latest American Ornithological Society taxonomy
Good for novice to experienced birders
Features a fold-out visual index and thumb tabs
cons: The binding isn't that good, leading the cover to separate or the glue to melt

customer_reviews.title: Stop the gossip about which field guide is better between NGS and Sibley
customer_reviews.text: OK Naysayers. Stop the gossip about which field guide is better between NGS and Sibley. They are BOTH superb, and they each have their strengths. Personally, for the field, I prefer NGS for the size and information provided. I keep Sibley in the car for a backup. The NGS guide is just so much better overall for fieldwork and birding (not to slight Sibley, which is wonderful). I find that identification keys, illustrations, behavior, and ease of use in the field is just better with NGS. The 7th edition has done its homework, and has come out with a winning product. You won't be sorry with the purchase. Dave Krueper Corrales, NM
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Beautiful comprehensive field guide with great features
customer_reviews.text: This field guide is beautiful and has some great features. There is a quick index on the inside front cover to make it easy to find things fast, and there are some pages that show raptors in flight from underneath, which is just brilliant. There is a ton of information in this book. It is my favorite field guide. I also have the Sibley's Eastern US guide and I prefer this one. It is well worth the price.
customer_reviews.author: jean

customer_reviews.title: Use better quality, heat resistant glue for the book binding
customer_reviews.text: I like the content of this book, but not the binding. I left this book on the front seat of my car on a summer day, and the glue from the binding melted and ran onto the seat. The book will never be the same. I have not had this problem with other bird books. Use better quality, heat resistant glue for the book binding.
customer_reviews.author: Wasatch Bill

customer_reviews.title: but this is the best ever. Besides being the most complete
customer_reviews.text: I have had several birding field guides before, but this is the best ever. Besides being the most complete, it includes most of the recent exotic species established in the states, and even includes an appendix of species found here only one or two times, but which could occur again. The color plates are the best I have ever seen. Perhaps some time in the future, it could include the birds of the USA islands like Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands.
customer_reviews.author: H. C. Cruzado

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Reference. Too Big for the Field.
customer_reviews.text: Excellent guide with good drawings and appropriate information on bird i.d., behavior and locales. However, it is too thick to carry into the field easily. I keep it as a reference book in the car and carry the thinner "Sibleys Western Guide" in my birding backpack. One can never have enough birding guides. I also gave it as a gift to a friend who just wanted it to i.d. backyard birds.
customer_reviews.author: Birder Girl

customer_reviews.title: I carry a guide to help others in the field enjoy their new found lifer
customer_reviews.text: The seventh ed. will go next to six other heavily notated editions as each edition improves upon the last,and changes to the nomenclature continue. Six months may pass before I scan every page. After fifty five plus years of birding I tend not to use a field guide but carry an old school pocket note book and take Grinnell style notes. I carry a guide to help others in the field enjoy their new found lifer.The seventh edition is well worth having.
customer_reviews.author: john westlake

customer_reviews.title: Good but too much inconsistency between illustrators.
customer_reviews.text: I really liked it but I encountered some problems with the inconsistency of the quality of the artwork. For example, compare the illustration of the Great Crested Flycatcher with the Indigo Bunting. Some artists that made the illustrations in the book seem to be much more skilled than others. Also, the quality of the printing is not optimal. Images tend to be darker than they appear in the field. For example, the Prothonotary Warbler does not appear as dark in the field (even in the shadow) as it is painted in this guide. The text and the maps are extraordinary.
customer_reviews.author: Walter S.

customer_reviews.title: These seldom disappoint. I don't take field guides into the field ...
customer_reviews.text: Another outstanding NG product. I have bought eveyr edition since they started coming out years ago...These seldom disappoint. I don't take field guides into the field anymore so like to have the latest edition on the reference shelf and the preceding edition in the truck for the folks I bird with.
customer_reviews.author: Salvia

customer_reviews.title: Nice reference book....
customer_reviews.text: I do wish that they had the common name of the birds in the appendix. I end up having to flip through looking at the pictures to find the bird in which I am interested or have seen. For instance, I wanted to find out a little more about mocking birds, but appendix does not have mocking bird. Otherwise, it is great. Lots of information about the birds. I particularly like that the size of the bird is listed. Helps me to rule out birds by size when trying to identify them.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Wonderful drawings, often in appropriate habitat
customer_reviews.text: An updated version of the classic field guide. Wonderful drawings, often in appropriate habitat, with seasonal distribution maps on the same page as the pictures and species description. I've been waiting for this update, and am so pleased with it. Even with it's awkward size, it is worth toting around in the field. Wonderful book, well-designed book.
customer_reviews.author: aspen lover

customer_reviews.title: A much improved edition!!!
customer_reviews.text: This is a very good update to the 6th ed. They have the most up-to-date splits/lumps and they have drastically improved a lot of the artwork. I loved the 6th edition but some of the illustrations (e.g., Magnolia Warbler) were terrible and didn't reflect the bird well. This revision is much better (the Maggie looks great!). They still maintain the best features of the 6th ed. like the quick finder flap and the tabs to the most common taxa. Overall I am much happier with the 7th edition!
customer_reviews.author: Seth

customer_reviews.title: Best bird ID book on the market since the Old Golden Book version
customer_reviews.text: The creators of this book did a very smart thing. They studied the best but very outdated Golden Book version, and then made it even better (except for the groupings of, say, all the 50 warblers' heads on two pages, which made for fast comparisons—those are gone in this edition). Still, every other detail that made the Golden Book so useful is here, and upgraded in quality, with a tough paper binding and quick-reference dimples cut into the pages where new sections start. Finally, a really good bird guide again after all these years. This is the 7th edition, of course, so it’s been around for a while, but I just discovered it, fully revised and updated in 2017.
customer_reviews.author: A. Matheny

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use field guide
customer_reviews.text: It's a little bigger and a lot heavier than my previous field guide from Golden Press, but a few species names and classifications have changed since 1966, so I sprang for it. Especially helpful, a flap inside each cover has half the index, where it's easy to find. Even better, inside those flaps, where they fold out from the covers, are spreads of visual guides to the general appearance of bird families. I only wish the book had a checklist for my life list of sightings. I have to keep my 1966 book for that.
customer_reviews.author: Jerry

customer_reviews.title: A great bird field guide
customer_reviews.text: We came upon this amazing book while on a Alaskan cruise in the ships library. We thought it was a terrific book with wonderful illustrations, maps and technical data. We came home and ordered the book. It will be a great resource in bird identification, migration patterns and seasonal plumage. We would highly recommend this book to amateurs to serious bird watchers.
customer_reviews.author: cimages2/Idaho

customer_reviews.title: Worth every penny!!!
customer_reviews.text: If you love birding, this is your bible. It has the most detailed bird images and great details on color variations and patterns. I have found it to be my most used bird book. It lives 24/7 on my table in front of our bird feeder window. Absolutely great content, maps are up to date, and the illustrations are brilliantly detailed.
customer_reviews.author: Gretchen C.

customer_reviews.title: Excellent, detailed book with lots of factual info
customer_reviews.text: Excellent, extremely detailed book. Shows illustrations of birds at rest and flying with lots of information about the birds and their location. Extremely factual, it does not give anecdotal evidence, eg. The fact that an anhinga looks like a snake when swimming or the cormorant can often be seen drying its wings is not included. I use this for a general idea and then the Stan Tekiela guide for our region for definite bird identification, as the Tekiela guides only show local birds, so far fewer options and easier to make an identification.
customer_reviews.author: Jennie

customer_reviews.title: Magnificent Book
customer_reviews.text: Purchased for friends just becoming enthralled with bird watching. Excellent resource for beginners and so complete, I even ordered a copy for our family who are long term bird watcher enthusiasts. Regardless of your experience in bird watching, you cannot go wrong with this book. Love the advantage, that unlike most of our own reference handbooks, this one is not limited to just "eastern" or "western" populations.
customer_reviews.author: sue

customer_reviews.title: Comprehensive, specific, good size images. You won't be disappointed!
customer_reviews.text: I have several field guides for birds and this one has been the most reliably useful. The illustrations are very clear (better in my opinion than photos for making identifications), and on several occasions when I've struggled to distinguish between similar species, the entry for a bird has pointed out some subtle but very clear distinguishing feature that I wouldn't have known to look for. Good information also about behavior, habitat, and range, with maps for each bird. Easy to navigate also, with side tabs to quickly jump to different bird types -- very helpful! Also, the images and text are a bit larger and easier to see than some similar guides.
customer_reviews.author: E A

customer_reviews.title: Lightweight, but durable book
customer_reviews.text: I recently bought this for a person newly moved to southern Florida. We discovered there were a LOT of birds there that we were unfamiliar with. This book has been used as a go to for identification purposes often. It's lightweight, but durable, and full of information. The price was right, and I'm very happy with the purchase.
customer_reviews.author: Cindy

customer_reviews.title: Great
customer_reviews.text: I bought this book and Sibley’s book after reading all the good reviews for each. This National Geographic guide is better to the extent it is slightly smaller and easier to carry in the field but I prefer Sibleya guide just slightly. Both are great.
customer_reviews.author: RIck Vander Weide

customer_reviews.title: Comprehensive guide to birds but no information on flavor an no catcing tips A review by the Cat
customer_reviews.text: This comprehenisve book is an excellent coffee type guide buy weigh more than I do and I'm a big 15 pound Cat. The content is missing important information on the nutrionlal value and taste and catching tips. This is the best field guide for most people cats. I really like the fold-out visual index, but it make me hungry. This was a review by the Cat. Meow.
customer_reviews.author: DylanMitchell

customer_reviews.title: Great book, but very fragile.
customer_reviews.text: The guide itself is great, offering useful descriptions and full color pictures. However, after less than two weeks it is beginning to fall apart. The cover is separating from the rest of the book. It has only ever been in a backpack and hasn't been mishandled. If returning it weren't such a hassle, that's what I would do.
customer_reviews.author: Jake

customer_reviews.title: Buy it.
customer_reviews.text: This makes an excellent complement to our 2001 "DK Publishing - Smithsonian Handbook - Birds of North America - Western Edition" and our 1998 "National Audubon Society Field Guide to North American Birds - Western Region". Always a good idea to cross-check multiple, creditable, sources and then triangulate the info. This has proven to be especially true in identifying new and previously unknown birds (i.e. Boreal Owls in Boise, ID). The Boreal Owl's normal range is Northern Canada and Southern Alaska but as shown in the book they do come down the Canadian and US Rockies into Idaho/Montana/Whyoming and then the Colorado Rockies. Idaho Fish and Game has confirmed our ID by call.
customer_reviews.author: Cloud Ripper

customer_reviews.title: Just what I wanted!!
customer_reviews.text: I was at first doubtful of the size to contain the information I wanted; doubts were not needed. This book contains alot of onfo; I love the fact that the male/female colors are provided! This is right size to fit in my pack. Maps to show areas of occupancy, tabs for easy reference, and so much more. Worth the cost and over!
customer_reviews.author: debjeff

customer_reviews.title: But...
customer_reviews.text: I love this book, don't get me wrong, and this is the second edition of it that I own. But, there is a flaw in it. When you come upon a flower, and go to your Peterson Wild Flower book to identify it, the book is arranged by color, making it easy to find what you are looking for. Bird books are not, and I wish they were.
customer_reviews.author: Carole L. Presberg

customer_reviews.title: We have always had this Bird Guide
customer_reviews.text: We bought this for our daughter for her leaving home with her first job out of college. We raised a bird lover just like us. We are very amateur bird watchers and this guide is easy to use and the illustrations are always accurate. Our guide is dog eared and worn; the best testament I would think to a field guide.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Reference Book for Bird Watchers
customer_reviews.text: I buy a new National Geographic Field Guide to the Birds of North America every year because it is updated annually with any new birds that occur in the US. It is the perfect book to use to help you identify birds when you are out in your own yard or visiting somewhere in the US.
customer_reviews.author: Enlightened Soul

customer_reviews.title: This is my "go to" bird book.  It's nice to have Sibley's as well.
customer_reviews.text: As good as it gets - I use this and sibley's guide.
customer_reviews.author: Alaska Nomad

customer_reviews.title: Reccomened by my college professor
customer_reviews.text: My college professor reccomended this book for her bird watching class. Very good feild guide with nice quick index and full index. My world is being expanded by each bird I learn to identify.
customer_reviews.author: Brooke

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Field Guide
customer_reviews.text: This is a very useful book. I like it a lot, and use it in conjunction with a couple of other field guides to birds. It helps to complete the picture of whatever bird I'm trying to identify. In my opinion there is no one field guide to birds that is so complete and perfect that it can be used alone. Every guide has a different approach, and it's that combination of approaches that cements identification. I appreciate the information it supplies; it has been very helpful.
customer_reviews.author: Susan L. Stone

customer_reviews.title: The Best Guide
customer_reviews.text: I am stubborn and thrifty so I've held on to my 30 year old field guide for far too long. This is a great improvement! It's a little heavy, but I like it the best of all my other guides for details and accuracy.
customer_reviews.author: BookLady

customer_reviews.title: A Must Have
customer_reviews.text: If you are bird watcher, you want this book. I bought it as a gift for a friend who is just discovering the fun and fascination of watching the variety of birds in her yard and she keeps it on her coffee table within easy reach. Great gift!
customer_reviews.author: Rebecca Gibson

customer_reviews.title: A little boring
customer_reviews.text: This is a very nicely done book. The pictures are beautiful. It's just a little scholarly for what we wanted. We're watching birds & enjoying them coming to the feeders not writing a college paper on them. Sorry.
customer_reviews.author: Sheila Graudons

customer_reviews.title: Quality book for bird watchers.
customer_reviews.text: Gift to my dad who is an avid bird watcher and he loved it. We thumbed through the pages and he learned a few new names right away. Beautiful color photos and sorted in a way you can quickly find a bird.
customer_reviews.author: WendiLouWho

customer_reviews.title: A Thing of Beauty
customer_reviews.text: My second edition will now be a car bird book. This is a grand bird - reference book. Easy to read, colored prints, and tons of maps. Plan on buying more for gifts. Well worth the money.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Beautifully Done! Informative!
customer_reviews.text: Such an amazing book! Beautiful pictures, incredibly detailed labels on all pictures, great indexing! Love this 7th edition! Keep it up National Geographic and thank you! Thanks Amazon for next day delivery too!
customer_reviews.author: Robert Boyle

customer_reviews.title: Overall nice
customer_reviews.text: Good book but unfortunately while this book covers many birds the one I needed to identify was not in it. (of course) I am guessing some type of hawk but only seen once. Next time, trail camera.
customer_reviews.author: Berkshire 484

customer_reviews.title: nice field guide but there's a taxonomic mistake...
customer_reviews.text: this field guide as the Tanagers in the Cardinal family. Thraupidae is the Tanager family.
customer_reviews.author: A. Davis

customer_reviews.title: A must have for birders.
customer_reviews.text: Excellent bird book, great descriptions, gives colors of juveniles and well arranged. We like it so much that we’re purchasing another copy for our vacation home.
customer_reviews.author: Karen

customer_reviews.title: Very Comprehensive
customer_reviews.text: This seventh edition field guide is great! Almost six hundred pages, over an inch thick, and easy to use. Beautifully illustrated as well. Only negative is that it"s a bit heavy for field use. But you can't have everything!! I highly recommend this field guide. You'll love it! Note: I've read from other reviews that it's important to get the 7th Edition.
customer_reviews.author: jack north

customer_reviews.title: Highly recommended!
customer_reviews.text: It took forever for NatGeo to come out with an updated version of this book, but it was well worth the wait. Highly recommended!
customer_reviews.author: Joe

customer_reviews.title: New and Improved -- Maybe the Best Bird Guide
customer_reviews.text: National Geographic's 5th edition of its Field Guide to the Birds of North America is very much improved. The illustrations are larger than those in other bird books I've used in the past, and the range maps have been both updated and enlarged. There are 80 more North American species in this edition -- 967 in all -- illustrated beautifully in color and accurately described by field marks, behavior, habitat, range, and vocalization. I especially like the handy thumbtabs -- very convenient for quick reference -- and this NatGeo 5th edition has a practical, weather-resistant cover and informative flaps that can be used as placeholders. There are other bird field guides, but this is the best I've seen.
customer_reviews.author: Robert R. Mendenhall

customer_reviews.title: Phenomenal
customer_reviews.text: Bought for a gift; arrived from vendor in excellent condition. Very high-quality hardcover edition. Excellent graphics and maps. Highly recommend
customer_reviews.author: FL Tman

customer_reviews.title: Beautiful, user-friendly resource for bird watchers
customer_reviews.text: Beautiful book! I’ve used the second edition for about 20 years and finally decided to upgrade. I didn’t think it could get any better but it did. Very nice quality, user-friendly for the non-expert, and beautiful illustrations that really help with identification. It would make a great gift for anyone interested in birds.
customer_reviews.author: J. Rohrer

customer_reviews.title: Many bird species illustrated
customer_reviews.text: Nice quality book. This was a gift for my significant other. Three bird feeders in the yard and a multitude of birds to identify.
customer_reviews.author: Ginger

customer_reviews.title: Bird Book not as good as Audobon
customer_reviews.text: Good book. However, I actually found the Audobon Field Guide easier to use than this bird book. It was delivered promptly.
customer_reviews.author: Ella

customer_reviews.title: National Geographic Field Guide to the Birds of North America, 7th Edition
customer_reviews.text: One of the field guide "bibles" out there! I have older editions, but when this 7th edition came out I had to have it! Recommended for birders!!
customer_reviews.author: Thomas Trenchard

customer_reviews.title: She Loves it
customer_reviews.text: This is an awesome book for novices and professional bird enthusiasts, my wife loves it, she's an avid bird watcher!!
customer_reviews.author: Jay

customer_reviews.title: Very comprehensive.
customer_reviews.text: I've used this book since the first edition, illustrations, descriptions, and range maps are all excellent. In Arizona it even confirmed the likelihood of a hybrid Pyrrhuloxia/Northern Cardinal !
customer_reviews.author: picasso2

customer_reviews.title: Birders Bible
customer_reviews.text: This is the birders bible. I have many other birding books (Peterson, Kaufman, Stokes, etc) but this is a “must have”
customer_reviews.author: M king

customer_reviews.title: Bought new looked used
customer_reviews.text: Book arrived with torn cover which was yellow from age! Outrageous price for what certainly had been either used or rejected by another person
customer_reviews.author: veda

customer_reviews.title: Best bird book yet
customer_reviews.text: I got this guide for my 13 daughter. It’s the best bird book we have. It’s got great identifying pictures and descriptions. We love it. No complaints
customer_reviews.author: momofthree

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Field Guide
customer_reviews.text: A little heavy in the backpack but this has all the info you need when out birding. Great quality book also.
customer_reviews.author: Kara S. Smith

customer_reviews.title: Outstanding book.
customer_reviews.text: Illustrations are better than pictures! Much better book than most of the picture-based books I’ve used.
customer_reviews.author: Scott M.

customer_reviews.title: Best field guide for US birders
customer_reviews.text: Although I have several other field guides this is my choice for bird walks. The illustrations are clear and detailed, and the accompanying maps ensure that likely species and the correct season are available. The quick index attached to the back cover makes it possible to quickly "look up" pictures of the likely species during identification. There are many other valuable field guides, but some of these are too complex for the average birder, or have photographic illustrations which make critical features difficult to see. Thus this should be the basic guide.
customer_reviews.author: rebugging

customer_reviews.title: Perhaps the best guide for North America north of Mexico.
customer_reviews.text: Though I already owned the 3rd edition the 7th edition was worth every penny. Finally with this edition the taxonomy is current. I bought a used copy but it looked new to me.
customer_reviews.author: Paul S Keller

customer_reviews.title: Excellent field guide
customer_reviews.text: Excellent field guide, highly recommend for both backyard birding or birding trips. Can be a little over whelmingn for new users. Best to supplement this guide with a regional guide as well if you are new to birding.
customer_reviews.author: GBanton

customer_reviews.title: Very detailed Bird descriptions.
customer_reviews.text: This is my first ever bird book. The individual bird descriptions are fantastic; however, the call description portion has me puzzled literally every time I read it.
customer_reviews.author: Carmen Fox

customer_reviews.title: Love this book
customer_reviews.text: I was interested in getting into bird identification. Did some research and decided on this book. Well organized and laid out with nice pictures and descriptions. As an amateur I’m very pleased with this book.
customer_reviews.author: Dan

customer_reviews.title: Nice reference guide to have on hand
customer_reviews.text: Great description of birds and color photos. Shipped on time with appropriate packaging
customer_reviews.author: sazzy

customer_reviews.title: Easy Bird Identification
customer_reviews.text: If you have a general interest in bird watching, this book is great. I would recommend this.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Terrific book
customer_reviews.text: Ought this for my shut in Aunt to be able to identify birds at her feeders. She loves it!
customer_reviews.author: Nancy I. Sirico

customer_reviews.title: Great field guide.
customer_reviews.text: Great field guide, needed an update and this was everything I needed. Great quality book.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Best guide on birds of North America
customer_reviews.text: I have had an older version of this guide for years. The cover has come off and its pages are tattered. I'm only a backyard bird watcher but I use this guide often. If you're looking for a guide that gives you the basics on birds and has excellent pictures of each bird this is the book for you. I can almost always identify a bird using this guide.
customer_reviews.author: Lee

customer_reviews.title: This is the best edition so far!
customer_reviews.text: I absolutely love this edition! The tabs make it so easy to find the bird you are looking for. Great job!
customer_reviews.author: mhwitt74

customer_reviews.title: Confusing
customer_reviews.text: Only problem is I’m trying to find one bird and because it’s the whole country I can’t
customer_reviews.author: Louise

customer_reviews.title: Exhastive bit brief bird atlas.
customer_reviews.text: Very complete bird atlas, typical high quality NG product. Very brief description of birds.
customer_reviews.author: Ancient Mariner

customer_reviews.title: Use this for our birdwatching class.
customer_reviews.text: Okay, this book is rather thick and heavy to carry around when you are bird watching in the outdoors. But we use it in our classroom and it is very informative and useful. We are happy with our purchase.
customer_reviews.author: Mindy Meedo

customer_reviews.title: Great bird watcher book
customer_reviews.text: This is a great book to have while in the field bird watching. Each species has adult and juvenile prints. Variations in in a species from one location to another are also shown. An index on the inside back cover makes finding birds quick if you know what species and group you are seeing. The size is small enough to take with you and to fit into a pouch/bag for carrying. Since I carry my binoculars on a harness, the book goes into the case with the strap on my shoulder and always handy.
customer_reviews.author: C Bear

customer_reviews.title: Great Field Guide
customer_reviews.text: Descriptions and illustrations are nicely detailed. But they’ll never make a movie out of it.
customer_reviews.author: T.Maxfield

customer_reviews.title: Large variety, great pictures, lot of detail
customer_reviews.text: Over all great book more than I expected. Very good for price, highly recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Monte J.

customer_reviews.title: Very happy with purchase.
customer_reviews.text: Very happy with purchase. Lovely book. Arrived in good order.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Love it!
customer_reviews.text: Ordered for my Ornithology class. Very informational! Love it! The pictures are great and very accurate.
customer_reviews.author: Taylor Sides

customer_reviews.title: Good reference.
customer_reviews.text: Great reference. And easy to use. Has helped me with the unusual visitors to my feeder.
customer_reviews.author: Beverly Paul

customer_reviews.title: Great Book
customer_reviews.text: This is a great book. Lots of pictures and descriptions.
customer_reviews.author: SLW

customer_reviews.title: This is my favorite field guide out of the 3 I own.
customer_reviews.text: I already own Sibley and Peterson’s field guides for eastern birds. I recently got this one and it has become my favorite, however, I like comparing the info in all 3 books
customer_reviews.author: S Burch

customer_reviews.title: Good reference but pretty heavy to pack
customer_reviews.text: its bigger than I thought it would be. Good reference but pretty heavy to pack around
customer_reviews.author: Thomas G. May

customer_reviews.title: National Geographic Field Guide to Birds of North America
customer_reviews.text: Like all books from National Geographic they are very well written, Great Pictures. Interesting reading and well made. I Great Book!
customer_reviews.author: Hammercl

customer_reviews.title: very good update to my favorite field guide for North American ...
customer_reviews.text: Very, very good update to my favorite field guide for North American birds... and i've tried and own almost all of them. Having started with Peterson's, I was blown away by the 5th edition of this field guide...and the latest update takes it up another notch. Highly recommended field guide!
customer_reviews.author: Icarus17

customer_reviews.title: really well done
customer_reviews.text: This is the birding book i have been looking for.
customer_reviews.author: Tom Bennett

customer_reviews.title: Excellent. Have only begun to use and enjoy this ...
customer_reviews.text: Excellent. Have only begun to use and enjoy this new edition, but have already appreciated the excellent visual comparisons between similar species. Information added to this new edition will help me continue building depth in my knowledge of birds. Thank you, Barbara, an enthusiastic birder, who highly recommends this edition. I have two of the previous editions.
customer_reviews.author: barbara ahlman

customer_reviews.title: Each version gets progressively better and the subspecies maps here are particularly useful
customer_reviews.text: Each version gets progressively better and the subspecies maps here are particularly useful. Several plates are beginning to seem dated and updates would have improved the book's quality. Planned obsolescence...?
customer_reviews.author: emp34157

customer_reviews.title: Update
customer_reviews.text: Glad to get the latest update of the bird guide I feel is the best around.
customer_reviews.author: P. Bomar

customer_reviews.title: Great price and fast seller!
customer_reviews.text: Great book for birdwatching lovers! The seller is great and shipped fast! I would highly recommend both the book and seller, great price!
customer_reviews.author: W. Wang

customer_reviews.title: National Geographic Best Photographers in the World
customer_reviews.text: Beautiful book. Informative and the National Geographic have the best photographers in the world and always have.
customer_reviews.author: Barry

customer_reviews.title: A little heavy but in a backpack or canvas bag with the binoculars is best.
customer_reviews.text: Excellent & Very nice and informative. Great detail and description of the birds and maps with migration. 591 pages in paperback and a little heavy but worthwhile a a guide.
customer_reviews.author: Steve Wargo

customer_reviews.title: necessary for any serious bird watcher
customer_reviews.text: excellent coverage of information needed to adequately understand and identify birds
customer_reviews.author: mswish

customer_reviews.title: Excellent pictures and notes
customer_reviews.text: Excellent pictures and notes. One of the best guides...if not the best. Easy to find a particular bird you are looking for.
customer_reviews.author: Bassmaster

customer_reviews.title: Excellent book for birdlovers!
customer_reviews.text: I am very pleased with this book. It is well written and the illustrations are fantastic. I've learned more about birds since this purchase, it's terrific. I've been eager to understand more about the birds that come to my feeders as well as recognize exactly what kind of birds they are. This book provides me with everything I need at this point in my hobby. My teenage son has been able to use it as a reference guide for some of his homework assignments, which proves it's worth even more to me. I would recommend it highly!
customer_reviews.author: Jayne C. Miller

customer_reviews.title: Good Book
customer_reviews.text: Good Reference and identifier - too bad it was printed in China!
customer_reviews.author: Wee Willie

customer_reviews.title: I like it best
customer_reviews.text: Name a field guide and I have it. This seems to be the best in describing the differences between very similar species. Artwork is good but sometimes the separation between the pictures of different species isn't quite clear at first glance.
customer_reviews.author: Jim  James

customer_reviews.title: Love the layout and the detail
customer_reviews.text: A little big to carry along while photographing, but an excellent reference.
customer_reviews.author: George W

customer_reviews.title: It is very good.
customer_reviews.text: I have been using this book in various editions since the late '70s. It is very good.
customer_reviews.author: White Woof

customer_reviews.title: The Standard
customer_reviews.text: The perfect bird guide - great illustrations (avoid guides with photos) and call-outs that help with distinguishing characteristics.
customer_reviews.author: P'ang

customer_reviews.title: Best bird book
customer_reviews.text: Love it. Bought this newest edition for a fellow bird watcher. Best bird book ever!
customer_reviews.author: Claire Frankel

customer_reviews.title: Wonderful Book
customer_reviews.text: We had this little book from my husbands youth on Birds, so many discovered or migrated here since then, wow. We couldn't find a bird in it, the Caracara, so I had to buy a new book. This book looked New! If it didn't have the first owner name in it, I would've thought it was. We are so pleased with the delivery of the book and the quality in the shape it was in, thank you very much THRIFTBOOKS.
customer_reviews.author: tkgrma

customer_reviews.title: My go to field guide for North America
customer_reviews.text: Best all around field guide out there. Bird pictures, range maps, geographical differences in birds of the same species, all included and all top notch. Being using this guide for over 10 years, all over North America.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Birds
customer_reviews.text: Beautiful book! Illustrations are wonderfully done and information is great
customer_reviews.author: mark Loop

customer_reviews.title: Great Field Guide
customer_reviews.text: I already owned the previous edition and found it to be great for identifying most birds. Wanted the most updated version.
customer_reviews.author: DWigg60196

customer_reviews.title: Nice!
customer_reviews.text: Awesome complete guide to all of the birds in North America, really enjoying this book, no shortage of info in here for the amateur bird watcher
customer_reviews.author: Jessie

product_meta.title: National Geographic Field Guide to the Birds of North America, 7th Edition
